item.name: 1754: Conquest – The French and Indian War
221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
Back to the Future: Back in Time
Back to the Future: Dice Through Time
BANG! The Dice Game: Old Saloon
Betrayal at House on the Hill
Blueprints
item.comment: One of the most creative uses of dice I've seen. Blueprints is sadly overlooked, because it truly is one of the greatest openers, not to mention a perfect gateway game. And just to sugar coat this wonderful production, the box is no bigger than it needs to be, which has to be applauded these days.

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
The Bridges of Shangri-La
item.comment:
Might be one of the most underappreciated board games ever designed; it's certainly one of the best.
You can only do one of two different actions on your turn, but the gameplay possibilities within that decision space are incredible. This game masquerades as a simple abstract, but it can ignite the same sensations as an epic wargame, full of drama and negotiation. And the constantly shrinking board gives the experience a tense, thematic appeal.
The combination of theme, art, and gameplay make this Colovini's undisputed masterpiece, at least in my eyes. It should be as well-regarded as T&E.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 8 – Bridges, Castles and Bazaars
Caylus
item.comment: This classic, early worker placement still holds up quite well in a marketplace full of hard-hitting competitors. I love how mean it is. If it wasn't for the length and somewhat drab theme (and therefore its' scarcity on the table), Caylus would be rated very highly for me.

item.name: Choose Your Own Adventure: House of Danger
Choose Your Own Adventure: War with the Evil Power Master
The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Dead of Winter: The Long Night
Dominant Species
item.comment: Somehow, this is simultaneously the most simple and most advanced worker placement game I've played. The balance between planning your turn with your action pawns and the tactility of maneuvering components on the board to maintain and procure dominance is truly brilliant. This game has it all. It just works, and I want it on the table right now.

item.name: Dragon Boats of the Four Seas
Dschingis Khan: Bewegung an der Großen Mauer
Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
Durch die Wüste
item.comment: Likely the best abstract to choose for three players, Through the Desert is a modern masterpiece.

item.name: En Garde
item.comment:
For being a simple game of numbered cards, mechanically speaking, this might be the most thematic game of all time?
Knizia's most clever design. My number two from him.
item.wishlistcomment: 3rd edition from 2007 by Ferti, normal version

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Expedition: Northwest Passage
item.comment: A vastly underrated and unique treasure. One of the finest marriages of mechanics and theme I've encountered. This is one of the only games that feels just as much like a tactical brain burner as it does an actual adventure. Anyone who criticizes this game is wrong. Want to play all the time, just wish others shared my enthusiasm.

item.name: The Field of the Cloth of Gold
item.comment: A game you want to keep playing over again. So quick, so dirty. You're usually deciding between two to three options, or maybe just one if your opponent is playing well. Seems restricting, but it's so fast-paced that the restriction itself becomes the most charming element.

item.name: Five Points: Gangs of New York
A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
Ghost Blitz
item.comment: Results in laughter and chaos with any group that plays it. It has to be a 10.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment:
Simply the greatest co-op/solo game for my tastes. It's a constantly evolving puzzle that provides tons of branching decisions while maintaining its core simplicity. It ties incredible artwork with a perfect theme, and it's just plain fun.
I recommend playing a variant in which you may choose to make your movement either before or after your action. Just trust me.

item.name: Ghost Stories: White Moon
item.comment:
Yes, it makes the game easier. But it also makes it more fun. You can add in more Wu Feng incarnations to scale the difficulty if you like.
Perfect expansion.

item.name: Holding On: The Troubled Life of Billy Kerr
In the Shadow of the Emperor
In the Year of the Dragon: 10th Anniversary
item.comment:
I can't even pinpoint what I love about this game exactly; it simply feels so good to play.
Something about preparing yourself for inevitable destruction must tick some hidden boxes for me, and each play results in wonderful game feel all the way through.

item.name: Java
item.comment: My second favorite of the masterful Mask Trilogy, Java is like no other game. It would be difficult to find another board game that makes you feel as clever as Java does when you plan and execute a successful turn. And due to the extraordinary, immersive artwork of the original, it's the only member of the trilogy I will never upgrade to the elaborate Super Meeple edition. I may purchase Cuzco one day just to add the beautiful resin palaces to my Java box, but we'll see.

item.name: Julius Caesar: Caesar, Pompey, and the Roman Civil War
The King Is Dead
item.comment:
There are eight rounds. You'll be lucky to play half of them. Winning or losing is always the width of a fingertip away, and you will only meet victory through clever play.
Amazing design.

item.name: KLASK
item.comment:
Probably the best dexterity game you can own for less than $200+
Every home should have KLASK. I have two for tournament play.

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment:
The best hidden movement game.
Once you wrap your head around the mechanics, the opportunities for strategy and deductive reasoning outrank any other similar game I've played, and I've legitimately played most of the pure hidden movement games that exist. LfW offers a psychological intensity you will not find elsewhere.
Best as a two player. Second best with full player count, though a completely different game.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
March of the Ants: Empires of the Earth
March of the Ants: Minions of the Meadow
Marco Polo II: In the Service of the Khan
Master of Orion: The Board Game
Menara
item.comment: It's a co-op dexterity stacking game. And it's incredible, but I guess that's redundant.

item.name: Mexica
item.comment:
This game is a shimmering jewel. I will play it anywhere, anytime.
How many area control games do you know in which you must, first, personally design the areas you'll be attempting to control? Both the player interaction and tactility of Mexica are phenomenal, and the Super Meeple edition transforms it into a true work of art. Mexica should be on every gamer's shelf.
The best of the Mask Trilogy for me.

item.name: My Very First Games: Animal upon Animal
Ninja: Legend of the Scorpion Clan
One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment:
The diminutive yet reigning king of social deduction games and the best way to penetrate the minds of your friends in just a couple of minutes, convincing them to kill their own mothers.
You can play this ten times in a row and immediately start another game without having to ask "Want to play again?"

item.name: Pente
item.comment:
A modern classic, Pente is like a knife fight in a knife booth.
What other abstract plays anywhere from 1 to 30 minutes and feels just as satisfying at either end of that spectrum?

item.name: Pyramix
item.comment: Pyramix is an interesting and attractive game. A strange quirk to this game, at least in all my plays, is that the newcomer always wins. It must be something to do with seat-of-your-pants play vs. faux strategic planning. Playing it enough makes you think you have it figured out, but you'll do much better to throw all that out the window and just pick some dice by feel. That probably means it's not a great game, but definitely a good gateway game.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado
item.comment:
My favorite racing game and deck builder rolled into one. Honestly, the game is genius. Knizia can't be stopped recently.
My wife will always play it, so how can you challenge that? In a just world, this game would be as well known as Monopoly and Clue. Should have won the SdJ over Kingdomino.

item.name: The Quest for El Dorado: The Golden Temples
Richard Scarry's Busytown: Eye found it! Game
Rick and Morty: Total Rickall Card Game
Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
Samurai Spirit
item.comment:
Might be one of the most thematic games of all time if you comprehend how the mechanics replicate the source content. It has the potential for alpha gaming, but with the right group or as a solo game, there's nothing like it.
This small box little brother to Ghost Stories is severely underrated and underappreciated.

item.name: Scooby-Doo Fright at the Fun Park
Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective: The Thames Murders & Other Cases
Spartacus: A Game of Blood and Treachery
Taluva
item.comment:
One of the best times you can have with a box of bits and tiles.
This abstract couldn't be any simpler, but it could be twice as fun... only if you get a second copy for Double Taluva of course.

item.name: Thing Two and Thing One Whirly Fun! Game
This War of Mine: The Board Game
Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment:
The greatest game of all time.
T&E is the most beautiful abstraction of theme into board game mechanics that can be found in the hobby. If it would have been designed hundreds of years previously, T&E would have already killed Chess.
I remember feeling a sense of awe the first time I played it as the options unfolded before me. I still feel that way every time I play.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment:
Tikal is my third rated in the Mask Trilogy, but it is no less a 10 for brilliant game design.
If you can handle the length, this is one of the most immersive experiences in board gaming even to this day.

item.name: Torres
item.comment:
Another K&K masterpiece. Designed for gamers who get excited at the promise of a bruised brain.
Skip the IDW edition due to the poor components. Find an earlier edition secondhand.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: My current favorite of the GIPF project, each game of TZAAR is incredibly tense with well-matched players. If you are a fan of themeless abstracts, this is the one to get.

item.name: War of the Ring: Second Edition
Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
